awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: CQIS: Recoverability and Markovianity in Quantum Information
awd_abstract_narration:
This NSF award aims to address foundational questions in quantum information regarding entropy inequalities such as the monotonicity of quantum relative entropy and strong subadditivity. These entropy inequalities are at the core of quantum information and more generally physics, underlying various capacities of quantum communication channels, entropic uncertainty principles, and certain formulations of the second law of thermodynamics. PI Wilde and collaborators have recently established the strongest refinements of these entropy inequalities in the 40 years since Lieb, Ruskai, and Lindblad proved them in the 1970s and in the 30 years since Petz characterized their equality conditions in the 1980s. These refinements have interpretations in terms of recoverability and Markovianity in certain setups to which the original entropy inequalities apply.

The PI, armed with these new theorems and other tools, will address fundamental questions regarding recoverability and Markovianity in quantum systems. These questions have been awaiting answers before the refined entropy inequalities were available. Since the use of quantum relative entropy is so widespread all throughout quantum information, there is a vast territory to explore in terms of recoverability and Markovianity, which may lead to fundamental insights into the nature of quantum information. The work developed with this NSF award may also influence other areas of physics, given that Markovianity and recoverability are such fundamental notions permeating all of science.

The broader impact of this proposal is in line with the NSF Mission "to promote the progress of science; to advance the national health, prosperity, and welfare; to secure the national defense; and for other purposes." Indeed, research at the intersection of physics, computer science, and mathematics has advanced science in remarkable ways, pushing the limits of what is possible in principle and in practice. A major goal of this proposal is to enhance the training of graduate students at LSU.

por.por_cntn:
The main outcome of this research project was to enhance our understanding of recovery of lost quantum information. Additionally, we explored a concept called Markovianity in quantum information, which is helpful for understanding the correlation structure of the state of multiple quantum systems. Both of these concepts are at the core of quantum information science and are helpful for enhancing our understanding of future quantum processors.

As key contributions, we developed an operational interpretation of a key information measure, conditional mutual information of a tripartite state, in terms of a task called conditional erasure. We showed that conditional mutual information is the minimal rate at which noise needs to be injected to the systems AE in order to erase the correlations between A and B given the information in system E, in such a way that there is only negligible disturbance on the marginal BE. This is fundamentally linked to the physics of information as well, and can be understood as a borad generalization of Landauer's erasure principle.

We also developed a general way of measuring the distinguishability of two quantum states, in terms of a measure called optimized f-divergence. This measure generalizes a notable measure called sandwiched Renyi relative entropy. We developed a novel method of proving the data processing inequality, which is a fundamental information inequality that says distinguishability cannot be increased by applying a common processing to both states. Later, we generalized this measure and the data processing inequality to more general classes of quantum states described by von Neumann algebras.

Among other contributions, we developed a quantum algorithm that can implement a recovery channel in quantum information called the Petz recovery map. This channel previously was a theoretical method for recovering lost quantum information---what our work shows is that it can actually be implemented on a quantum computer. The method requires a fault-tolerant quantum computer, and so it will be some years before it can be implemented on working devices. However, it is useful to know now that it can be implemented in principle, and we determined the running time of this algorithm, showing in some cases that it is efficient.

In summary, our work has advanced our knowledge of recoverability and Markovianity in quantum information, and it will lead to future advances in the area of quantum Bayesian inference, which will be important for the foundations of quantum machine learning.
